name: Coral Reef Restoration Explorer
text: To begin, select a region to view.
globalText: Modify the sliders to change the values on the map (refresh takes a couple seconds).
infoGraphic:
The coral reef restoration explorer allows multi-sector stakeholders to examine both ecological and socioeconomic factors for prioritizing restoration efforts. This tool provides a regional platform to consider important coral reef larvae connectivity indicators (such as the amount of estimated larvae contributed and the ability to self-recruit) as well as integrating high priority nodes that are important for maintaining connectivity health. In addition, users can explore two ecosystem service models that reefs provide:

1) Coastal vulnerability - highlights the protective services offered by coastal habitats to coastal populations. This information can be used to identify regions of greater risk to coastal hazards (such as erosion and flooding), which can in turn better inform development strategies and permitting.
2) Recreation and tourism – predicts tourist visitation and recreation rates, based photo-user-days from geotagged photos in the flicker database, highlighting patterns of tourism and recreational use around coral reefs.

Coral reefs require a number of ecological factors to ensure restoration success. This tool can be used to align these ecological factors with where coral reefs provide benefits to humans. Users can explore both the ecological and human benefits to evaluate and prioritize potential restoration areas. The darker blue areas indicate a higher likelihood of success for restoration activities based on user-defined settings.
